attributes.title: Evaluating A Multi-site Replication of Providence Talks
attributes.description: Providence Talks attempts to close the word gap that occurs among children of differing socioeconomic backgrounds. It uses LENA devices, home visiting, play groups, etc. to help parents speak more with their children. The Policy Lab is coordinating a multi-site evaluation between the five cities participating in the Providence Talks Replication Initiative. This document contains the initial version of our evaluation plan.

q2.value: David Yokum, Jake Bowers, Matthew J. Lyddon

attributes.title: COVID-19 Face Masks and Ideology
attributes.description: This project examines how liberals and conservatives respond differently to messages about wearing facemasks.

q2.value:
Messages related to promotion will increase the likelihood that liberals comply with recommendations about facemasks.

Messages related to prevention will increase the likelihood that conservatives comply with recommendations about facemasks.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Between subjects design. Control group, Promotion Message, Prevention Message. Interacted with respondent ideology.

Experimental Texts 

Control:

The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has recently recommended that all Americans wear a facial mask when leaving their homes, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

Prevention:
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has recently recommended that all Americans wear a facial mask when leaving their homes, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

Following this recommendation will help us prevent Americans from dying, and prevent our economy from entering a long-term recession.

Promotion:
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has recently recommended that all Americans wear a facial mask when leaving their homes, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

Following this recommendation will help us to keep Americans healthy, and allow our economy to return to normal more quickly. 
 
Ideology measure.

We hear a lot of talk these days about liberals and conservatives.  Here is a seven-point scale on which the political views that people might hold are arranged from extremely liberal to extremely conservative.  Where would you place yourself on this scale, or haven't you thought much about this?
o	Very liberal  (1) 
o	Liberal  (2) 
o	Somewhat liberal  (3) 
o	Moderate / Middle of the road  (4) 
o	Somewhat conservative  (5) 
o	Conservative  (6) 
o	Very conservative  (7) 
o	I haven't thought much about this  (8)

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via Amazon's Mechanical Turk. The overall study should take less than 2 minutes to complete, and participants will be paid 25 cents for participation.

q12.value: Given that general compliance with regulations is high, it is likely that the effects of messaging will be small. Using a Cohen’s d of a small effect, this would require 139 participants per experimental condition, of which there are 3. However, given that only about 1/3 of respondents on MTurk, I will seek 3 times that may participants to ensure enough conservatives per group. This would give 417 respondents per experimental condition, for a total of 1251 respondents.

question.value:
Control:

The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has recently recommended that all Americans wear a facial mask when leaving their homes, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

Prevention:
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has recently recommended that all Americans wear a facial mask when leaving their homes, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

Following this recommendation will help us prevent Americans from dying, and prevent our economy from entering a long-term recession.

Promotion:
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has recently recommended that all Americans wear a facial mask when leaving their homes, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

Following this recommendation will help us to keep Americans healthy, and allow our economy to return to normal more quickly.

Ideology measure.

We hear a lot of talk these days about liberals and conservatives.  Here is a seven-point scale on which the political views that people might hold are arranged from extremely liberal to extremely conservative.  Where would you place yourself on this scale, or haven't you thought much about this?
o	Very liberal  (1) 
o	Liberal  (2) 
o	Somewhat liberal  (3) 
o	Moderate / Middle of the road  (4) 
o	Somewhat conservative  (5) 
o	Conservative  (6) 
o	Very conservative  (7) 
o	I haven't thought much about this  (8) 


Outcome measures
Each will be measured on a 0 (strongly disagree) to 100 (strongly agree) scale. The first will be a behavioral intention question – “I will wear a mask every time I leave my home.” The next two will be attitudinal questions – “It is best for society if everyone wears a mask when they leave their home” and “I don’t think wearing a mask will impact the spread of the coronavirus.”

OLS regression analysis. 

Variables for treatment (promotion and prevention, with control as reference)
Variable for self-reported ideology
Interaction of each treatment with self-reported ideology

Controls for demographics (age, gender, education, race).

q18.value:
Ideology will be recoded as follows:

Respondents who answer “Very conservative,” “conservative,” or “somewhat conservative” will be coded as “conservative,” while those who answer “very liberal,” “liberal,” or “somewhat liberal” will be coded as “liberal.” This creates a dichotomous measure of ideology, with individuals coded as either conservative (1) or liberal (0). 

	Those who report their ideology as “moderate / middle of the road” or respond that they “haven’t thought much about this” will be excluded from analysis.

q19.value: One-tailed test, because of directional hypotheses. P value of .05, one-tailed.

q20.value: Those who report their ideology as “moderate / middle of the road” or respond that they “haven’t thought much about this” will be excluded from analysis.

attributes.title: Dana 2013
attributes.description: This experiment analyzes the persistent use of unstructured interviews despite the fact that there are numerous studies to discourage the use of them. it includes data showing that unstructured interviews can actually be harmful in job performance prediction and questions why interviewers are still more confident and think they receive more valuable information than if they were to perform structured interviews or other methods.

q1.value: Structured or Unstructured Interviews and Job Predictability

q2.value: Elyse Arnold, Tatianna PuertoReal, Honor Herring, Kaycie Allen , peyton

q4.value: Structured interviews are better predictors of job outcomes than unstructured interviews, but people will continue to value unstructured interviews or structured ones.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Study 1
One hundred undergraduates participated in this study. Students were randomly assigned to interviewers and were told the interviewee's age, major, class standing, and course schedule. After conducting the interview, the interviewer was to predict the interviewee's GPA. Before their prediction, they were given the interviewee's cumulative GPA. Before their prediction, they were given the interviewee's cumulative GPA for the semester before the one in question. They were then told to comment on it if they believed that they were given good information from the interviewee. Lastly, 74 students were told to predict a student's GPA based on their background information and cumulative GPA from the semester prior to the one in question. 

Study 2
Sixty-four undergraduates participated in this study. Eight participants consented to be interviewed twice (one random, one accurate) while being recorded. The remaining participants were randomly assigned one interview to watch, each interview having four viewers. They were then asked post-interview questions answered using a Likert-Scale from one to five, middle being "Neither Agree Nor Disagree". After answering these questions, participants were told that the interviews they watched were randomly selected from half accurate and half random interviews and were then asked to predict which they believed was theirs. 

Study 3
One hundred and sixty-nine undergraduates participated in this study. Students were given descriptions of methods and conditions used in Study 1 (the participants were given previous GPA to use as a reference) and were asked to predict a student's GPA from a specific semester. The participants were then asked to rank the interview types on which they would rather have in order to help make these predictions more accurate.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Study 1
A twenty-minute interview was conducted by the participants who were then asked to predict the GPA of a randomly assigned interviewee based on the interview and given prior knowledge. After predicting the interviewee's GPA, the interviewers were given a questionnaire asking about the usefulness of the information gathered during the interview. Then sixty-eight of the participants guessed the GPA of a student without an interview, using only given prior knowledge. 

Study 2
Eight undergraduates (five female, three male) aged nineteen to twenty-one were interviewed twice, random and accurate while being recorded. These interviews were shown to fifty-six participants and evaluated to determine if they got valuable information from the interviews. 

Study 3
Students were given descriptions of the methods used in Studies 1 and 2, then were asked to guess the GPA of a student. They then ranked the order that the information from these studies should be given to them to allow for the most precise GPA prediction.

q13.value:
Study 1: 100 undergraduate student participate. 
Study 2: 64 undergraduate students participate.
Study 3: 169 undergraduate students participate.

question.value: Study 1 manipulated the knowledge that was given to the interviewer including class standing, course schedule, GPA of previous semesters, and whether there was an interview given or not.

Study 1
The knowledge given to the interviewer is being manipulated (class standing, course schedule, GPA of previous semesters, interview or no interview) to best predict the GPA of the participant. 

Study 2
The type of interview being shown to the participants is randomized to measure their confidence in its accuracy. 

Study 3
Measured (ordinal) what participants believed to be the most useful interview type from Studies 1 and 2.

Multiple Regression Analysis for Study 1
The predictors were: actual GPA, access to the interview, actual GPA and interview. 

ANOVA for Study 2
Comparing (random, accurate, and total) to (guess random, guess accurate, and total).

subjects.text: Design of Experiments and Sample Surveys

attributes.title: Fear and Distance
attributes.description: We will be looking at how fear of an object effects the perception of distance we have of that object. Our hypothesis is that when a person is more fearful of a stimulus then they will perceive it closer than it actually is.

q1.value: How Distance Perception is Affected by Fear

q2.value: Luke Harris, Elisabeth Fontenot, Abbey Richardson, Emma Armstrong, Faith Brown

q3.value: Research has shown that threat perception affects distance perception in a linear fashion. Following prior studies on the matter, we are going to place a live tarantula in a class room and have participants report the degree to which they feel threatened and disgusted by the tarantula. Since those two emotions are conceptually independent there should be a difference between the distance perception when something considered threatening rather than disgusting, as was demonstrated by experiments conducted in the past.

q4.value: We predict that the tarantula would be seen as physically closer to the extent that it was threatening but not to the extent that it was disgusting.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional design with 2 factors (measure of affect and measure of perceived distance) and 3 levels for affect (fear, disgust, neutral) and 2 factors of distance (closer or further). We will recruit participants from an undergrad program and tell them they will participant in a survey about their thoughts on "island life".  They will enter a room where we have placed a live tarantula on a tray, and be told to stand in a specific spot that we marked 156 in. away from the spider. We will then ask them to fill out a questionnaire while looking at the spider that will assess how fearful, disgusted, or neutral the tarantula made them feel on a 7-point Likert scale. Then they will indicate how far they feel they are from the tarantula in inches.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The subjects of this experiment will include 101 undergraduate students, who will be given extra credit in exchange for participating.

q13.value: In order to effectively replicate the original study, we will aim for a sample size of 101 undergraduate students.

q14.value: They will be offered extra credit to participate.

question.value: The independent variable is the measured distance between the participant and the tarantula (156 inches).

The dependent variable/outcome measure, fear in participants, will be measured by use of of a Likert Scale  where participants will estimate their perceived distance between themselves and the tarantula.
We will run a regression analysis to test the relationship that each emotion had to distance estimation. This regression analysis predicted participants'

q20.value: The "Effect of fear in distance perception" will not require and transformations. Since we will be using a regression analysis, each level of fear/disgust will be categorically described (e.g. more fear than disgust, more disgust than fear, same fear and disgust), Threat as primary feeling = -1, equal feelings = 0, disgust as primary feeling = +1

q21.value: We are only testing one hypothesis so we will not have to account for that. We will use p-values to determine the significance. We will be using a two tailed test.

q23.value: We will get rid of any incomplete or missing data.

q24.value: We do not plan on exploring data for unspecified differences or relationships.

q25.value:
This study replicated the experiment done by Cole, Balcetis, and Dunning (2013). 
Cole, S., Balcetis, E., & Dunning, D. (n.d.). Affective Signals of Threat Increase Perceived Proximity. PSYCHOLOGICAL SCIENCE, 24(1), 34–40. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797612446953

attributes.title: Laptop usuage effect on classroom performance
attributes.description: This study will examine the relationship between academic and nonacademic internet usage via laptops in a classroom setting and the effect on academic performance.

q1.value: How laptop ususage relates to classroom learning

q2.value: Brandon  Rico, Jennifer LeGeaux, Ashlyn Guillaumin, Katherine Rose, Alexandra Herman

q4.value:
One possible reason for this disconnect is that students have better insight into what is causing them to browse the Internet and are attributing their performance to this explanation.

Another possible reason for this disconnect is the use of subjective reports about Internet use.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a correlational study design assessing the relationship between average internet use (average duration online & average number of requests) for academic or non-academic purposes and classroom performance. Time, frequency, and participants' browsing history will be objectively measured, while past research relied on self-report.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will invite the students enrolled in the spring 2020 introductory psychology class to participate in our study and will receive course credit. Participants must be able to use their laptops during the lecture periods. We will only look at the students who logged into the proxy server during the 15 lectures to collect our data.

q13.value: We will invite the students that are enrolled in the introductory psychology class to participate in the experiment for course credit. Our goal is to receive as many participants as possible. Our sample size will consist of the students who log into the proxy server.

question.value: There will be four measured variables in this experiment. The first variable is going to be the amount of internet used. It is going to measured by looking at the proxy server that the students used. This one variable will be divided into two parts the average duration online (This is an estimate of the average minutes a participant spends on the internet) and average number of requests (The average number of HTTP requests a participant made during each lecture). The next variable is going to be self-reported internet use which is where the participants report their internet use via survey. The third variable will be classroom performance. This is going to be the student's academic performance in relation to internet usage (cumulative final-exam score). The final variable will be intelligence, and will be measured in the composite ACT scores of the students.

For the actual internet usage will be the average duration online and average number of requests. Self-reported internet use will be the mean of fifteen surveys that will be administered. Classroom performance will be the cumulative final-exam score. finally intelligence will be the students' composite ACT scores.

A hierarchical multiple linear regression analysis will be used to evaluate the relationship between nonacademic Internet use and final-exam score while accounting for intellectual ability, motivation and interest. The hierarchical regression model will also be used to assess whether the correlations would account for variance in final exam score when we control for the impact of the participant's motivation, interest, and intelligence. A Fisher's r-to-z transformation will be used to examine the correlation between intellectual ability and internet use for nonacademic purposes.

attributes.title: Treatment with direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) in patients with morbid obesity: A systemic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: In this systematic review meta-analysis, we seek to obtain summary estimates of the safety and efficacy of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) and vitamin K antagonists in obese patients (weight ≥ 100 kg) and morbidly obese patients (weight ≥ 120 kg and/or BMI ≥ 40 kg/m2) for the prevention of recurrent venous thromboembolism (VTE) in patients on anticoagulation for VTE or stroke prevention in patients on anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation.

q1.value: Tzu-Fei Wang, Aurelien Delluc, Marc Carrier

q2.value: DOACs are associated with comparable risk of recurrent VTE or stroke when compared to vitamin K antagonists, with similar or lower risk of bleeding.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Meta-analyses and systemic review on observational studies, prospective or retrospective (cohort study or case series of >=20 patients), case-control studies, or randomized controlled trials including obese adult patients (weight ≥ 100 kg) who received either DOAC or vitamin K antagonists for the treatment of VTE or atrial fibrillation and reported outcomes of interest. Case reports or studies published in abstract only will be excluded. The studies that will be considered include:
1)	Studies comparing DOACs vs vitamin K antagonists
2)	Studies using DOACs only, comparing among weight/BMI groups

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: An electronic search of the following databases until April 2020 will be performed (without restriction of year or language): PubMed, Embase, Scopus, CENTRAL (Cochrane), for Observational studies, prospective or retrospective (cohort study or case series of >=20 patients), case-control studies, or RCTs including obese adult patients (weight ≥ 100 kg) who received either DOAC or vitamin K antagonists for the treatment of VTE or AF and reported outcomes of interest. Ongoing trials will be explored by looking up in ClinicalTrials.gov. Adjustments will be made to the search strategy to account for the differences in indexing between databases. Duplicates will be removed prior to analyzing these articles. Additionally, a manual search will be performed to identify relevant abstracts presented at the last editions of relevant conferences. Two reviewers will independently screen records, abstracts, and extract data in standardized data collection forms.

q11.value: We expect to identify at least 20 studies.

question.value: N/A

The primary efficacy outcome is the rate of recurrent VTE in either class of oral anticoagulant in the obese with VTE, as well as the rate of stroke or systemic embolism in the atrial fibrillation population. 
Studies that reported on at least one of the following outcomes will be included:
Primary efficacy outcome: VTE recurrence, stroke, TIA, or systemic embolism 
Primary safety outcomes: major bleeding according to the ISTH criteria
Secondary outcomes (if available): clinically relevant non-major bleeding according to the ISTH criteria; VTE-related death; all-cause mortality

Primary and secondary outcomes will be reported by narrative synthesis and pooled rate estimates (latter if feasible). To estimate the weighted rates and 95% CIs for the review’s primary outcomes, individual study estimates will converted to rates per patient-month of follow-up on the basis of the mean (or median) reported follow-up. The rates will be transformed by using the Freeman–Tukey arcsine square root transformation before pooling the outcome rates. A DerSimonian–Laird random-effects model will be used to pool the transformed rates. After pooling the resulting estimates and their 95% CIs, limits will be back-transformed to rates per patient-month of follow-up. 
The I² statistic will be calculated using a forest plot and I² below 30% will be determined as non-significant heterogeneity, an I² between 30-70% as moderate heterogeneity and an I² greater than 70% as considerable heterogeneity. Funnel plots will be generated to assess for publication bias if number of included studies are greater than ten.

q23.value: The qualify of studies will be assessed using the ROBINS-I tool (https://methods.cochrane.org/methods-cochrane/robins-i-tool).

attributes.title: Gender Identity Study 1
attributes.description: The current study plans to examine whether the neglect of trans women who are sexually harassed is driven in part by the perception that trans women are less gender-prototypical than cis women, leading to the biased perception that harassment targeting trans women (vs. cis women) is less credible, is less harmful, and should be punished less severely.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Study 1: Gender identity and perceptions of sexual harassment.

other.value: As a gender identity manipulation check, we will ask participants whether Sarah was described as being transgender or cisgender. We will use a chi-squared test to examine whether gender identity perceptions differ between the ‘transgender’ and ‘cisgender’ conditions. If they do not, we will conclude that our manipulation was unsuccessful and thus that our hypotheses cannot be tested. We will also examine if participants’ gender is a moderator for our outcomes given that men and women often perceive ambiguous sexual harassment differently.

sample.value: We aim to recruit 425 participants to obtain a sample of at least 398 participants after exclusions (d = .25, alpha = .05, power = 80%, two-sided independent t-test). (G*Power software; Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009).

analyses.value: We will use independent samples t-tests to examine whether the credibility, psychological harm, punishment recommendation, and gender-prototypicality ratings of Sarah differ by transgender and cisgender conditions. Further, we will use Hayes’ (2013) PROCESS macro for SPSS to conduct three bias-corrected mediation analysis with 5,000 samples to examine whether gender-prototypicality mediates the effect of gender identity on credibility, psychological harm, and punishment decisions.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who fail the attention checks and/or respond that they answered randomly

dependent.value:
Credibility. Participants will be told that Sarah has made a sexual harassment claim against a coworker. They will then rate how much they believe and how confident they are that Jessica was harassed by her coworker on a 7-point scale, with higher numbers indicating higher belief/confidence. These items will be averaged to create a composite ‘credibility’ score. 
Psychological Harm. Participants will be asked to evaluate how psychologically harmed (upset, distressed, traumatized) Jessica would be if she was harassed by her coworker on a 1 to 7 scale, with higher numbers indicating stronger emotional reactions. These three items will be averaged to create a composite ‘psychological harm’ score.
Punishment Recommendation. Participants will be told that company policy has a 9-tiered system of punishment severity that is used to determine appropriate punishment when sexual harassment occurs within the company.  They will then be asked ‘if an investigation concludes that Jessica was sexually harassed by her coworker, how should the coworker be punished?’ on a 1 (Level 1: informal warning) to 9 (Level 9: termination) scale. 

Gender-Prototypicality. Next, participants will rate the gender prototypicality of Sarah using four items on a 1 to 7 scale: (1) Sarah has a lot in common with other women; (2) Sarah is similar to other women; (3) Sarah is feminine; and (4) Sarah is masculine (reverse); with higher numbers indicating higher levels of agreement. These four items will be averaged to create a ‘gender prototypicality’ composite.

conditions.value: There are two conditions (cisgender vs. transgender). This is a between-subjects design. Each participant will be randomly assigned via Qualtrics to evaluate the transgender or cisgender woman.

hypothesis.value: The current study plans to examine whether the neglect of trans women who are sexually harassed is driven in part by the perception that trans women are less gender-prototypical than cis women, leading to the biased perception that harassment targeting trans women (vs. cis women) is less credible, is less harmful, and should be punished less severely. Participants will read a description of a woman named Sarah who is either described as cisgender (“Sarah is a cisgender woman, which means she identifies as a woman and was assigned female at birth”) or transgender (“Sarah is a transgender woman, which means she identifies as a woman and was assigned male at birth”). Filler information, such as her age, where she lives, etc., will also be included in the description. After reading about Sarah, participants will be told that Sarah recently made a sexual harassment claim against a coworker and will answer questions concerning the credibility of her claim as well as how harmed she would be and how the perpetrator should be punished if she was sexually harassed by her coworker. We expect that people will perceive a transgender woman to be less gender-prototypical compared to a cisgender woman (Hypothesis 1). We also expect that a sexual harassment claim made by a transgender woman (vs. cisgender woman) will be perceived to be less credible (Hypothesis 2). Further, we predict that sexual harassment will be perceived to be less psychologically harmful (Hypothesis 3) and perpetrators will be punished less severely (Hypothesis 4) when a transgender (vs. cisgender) woman is targeted. Finally, we expect that perceived gender-prototypicality will mediate the effects in Hypotheses 2-4 (Hypothesis 5).

attributes.title: The Coronavirus Crisis
attributes.description: The purpose of the study is to test seven hypotheses related to the dynamics of institutional and social trust during the coronavirus crisis.

q2.value:
H1a: The coronavirus crisis increases levels of institutional trust. 
H1b: If the coronavirus crisis is made salient, then levels of institutional trust increase.
H2: The coronavirus crisis increases levels of social trust. 
H3a: The coronavirus crisis increases the polarization of institutional trust.
H3b: If the coronavirus crisis is made salient, then there is greater polarization of institutional trust.
H4: The coronavirus crisis increases the polarization of social trust.
H5: A higher level of institutional trust leads to a higher level of social trust.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Our study primarily relies on two panel waves (T0 and T1). Data collection for T0 took place between February 24, 2020 and March 19, 2020, and data collection for T1 began on March 31, 2020. Data collection for T1 is not yet complete, and we have not received the data from either T0 or T1. T1 has an embedded between-group priming experiment where a third of the invited participants are assigned to the treatment group while the rest are assigned to the control group. The experiment is explained below. We also have information on institutional trust and social trust collected before the coronavirus outbreak. These measures are referred to as T-1. While the focus of the hypotheses are on T0 and T1, when possible, the T-1 measures will be used to explore if there have been changes from T-1 compared to T0 and T1.

q7.value: Simple randomization is used for the experiment embedded at T1.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: The researchers that conduct the data analysis have not studied the data from either T0 or T1 and are not aware of any data patterns from the panel steps or the embedded experiment conducted at T1. Since we have not examined data from either of T0 or T1, we are unaware of data patterns from T-1 to T0 or T1. The data is collected by the Laboratory of Opinion Research at the University of Gothenburg. They will release the data from T0 to the researchers when the pre-analysis plan is registered. Data from T1 will be delivered to the researchers once data collection is completed.

question.value: Participants are drawn from a panel that is maintained by the Laboratory of Opinion Research at the University of Gothenburg. Participants receive no payment. Data collection for T0 took place between February 24, 2020 and March 19, 2020, and data collection for T1 began on March 31, 2020. Data collection for T1 is not yet complete.

q11.value: In total, 18 045 individuals were invited to participate at T0. Of those, 12 881 participated. The same participants, except 37 who opted out after T0, were invited to participate in T1.

q12.value: Sample size calculations are difficult since it is hard to guess effect sizes. That said, each mean will be based on over 1000 participants, which, in general, makes it possible to detect even very small effects.

question.value: At T1, we conducted a priming experiment about the coronavirus outbreak. Immediately before answering the question on government authorities (“Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?”), we randomly assign a portion of the respondents to write about their own thoughts on the coronavirus and its consequences. Specifically, for this group, the treatment group, we ask: “The coronavirus and its consequences are discussed a lot right now. We would really like to know more about your thoughts on the effects of the coronavirus and its results. Write down your thoughts in the box below.” The purpose of reading, thinking and writing about the coronavirus is to prime corona-relevant thoughts among the respondents. The control group receives the same task of writing their own thoughts on the coronavirus at the end of the survey instead. For them, the first question at both T0 and T1 is about institutional trust.

Attitudes on institutional trust is measured with the following question at both T0 and T1: “Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?” There are five response options to the question, “Very high trust,” “Rather high trust,” “Neither high nor low trust,” “Rather low trust,” and “Very low trust.” 

At both T0 and T1, social trust is measured by asking: “In your opinion, to what extent is it generally possible to trust people?” There are five response options, “1 People cannot generally be trusted,” “2,” “3,”, “4,” and “5 People can generally be trusted.”

Increase in trust hypotheses

H1a: The coronavirus crisis increases levels of institutional trust. 

H1a is tested by examining change over time, between panel waves. We expect there to be a mean increase in the level of support for Swedish government authorities between T0 and T1 because the outbreak of the coronavirus reached a more acute crisis stage at T1. 

Attitudes towards government authorities is measured with the following question at both T0 and T1: “Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?” There are five response options to the question, “Very high trust,” “Rather high trust,” “Neither high nor low trust,” “Rather low trust,” and “Very low trust.” 

In the analysis, response options will be recoded to range from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating a greater level of trust. A statistically significant higher group mean value at T1 compared to T0 according to a t-test (p < 0.05) would yield support for the hypothesis. The analysis will rely on the individuals who gave a valid response (i.e. used one of the available five response options) to the question at both T0 and T1, and were not part of the treatment group at T1 (see below under H1b). 

We will also explore if the mean of institutional trust at T-1 is lower compared to T0 and T1. 

H1b: If the coronavirus crisis is made salient, then levels of institutional trust increase.

At T1, we conducted a priming experiment about the coronavirus outbreak. Immediately before answering the question on government authorities (“Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?”) (i.e. the same question above with the same response options), we randomly assign a portion of the respondents to write about their own thoughts on the coronavirus and its consequences. Specifically, for this group, the treatment group, we ask: “The coronavirus and its consequences are discussed a lot right now. We would really like to know more about your thoughts on the effects of the coronavirus and its results. Write down your thoughts in the box below.” The purpose of reading, thinking and writing about the coronavirus is to prime corona-relevant thoughts among the respondents. The control group receives the same task of writing their own thoughts on the coronavirus at the end of the survey instead. For them, the first question at both T0 and T1 is about institutional trust. A statistically significant higher mean value for the treatment group in comparison to the control group (p < 0.05) according to a t-test would yield support for the hypothesis. The analysis will rely on the individuals who gave a valid response to the question at T1 (i.e. used one of the available five response options).

H2: The coronavirus crisis increases levels of social trust. 

The test of H2 relies on a similar approach as the test of H1a in that it focuses on change over time. Here, however, the focus is on social trust and not institutional trust. At both T0 and T1, social trust is measured by asking: “In your opinion, to what extent is it generally possible to trust people?” There are five response options, “1 People cannot generally be trusted,” “2,” “3,”, “4,” and “5 People can generally be trusted.” 

In the analysis, response options will be recoded to range from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating a greater level of trust. A statistically significant higher group mean value at T1 compared to T0 according to a t-test (p < 0.05) would yield support for the hypothesis. The analysis will rely on the individuals who gave a valid response (i.e. used one of the available five response options) to the question at both T0 and T1, and were not part of the treatment group at T1 (see below under H1b).

We will also explore if the mean of social trust at T-1 is lower compared to T0 and T1. 

We will also explore if the priming experiment increases social trust, but do not formulate a hypothesis regarding this (similar to H1b) because the outcome variable is placed further down in the questionnaire. 


Polarization hypotheses

H3a: The coronavirus crisis increases the polarization of institutional trust.

This hypothesis concerns potential heterogenous changes in institutional trust as a consequence of the coronavirus outbreak. We will study this by comparing changes in attitudes from T0 and T1. Individuals at the lower end of trust and individuals at the higher end of trust are expected to diverge more on institutional trust at T1 compared to T0. A statistically significant test (p < 0.05) in the proposed direction would yield support for the hypothesis. Participants in the treatment group at T1 will not be part of this analysis. 

As before, we rely on the following question: “Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?” There are five response options to the question, “Very high trust,” “Rather high trust,” “Neither high nor low trust,” “Rather low trust,” and “Very low trust.” 

We will also explore if there is less polarization on institutional trust at T-1 compared to T0 and T1. 


H3b: If the coronavirus crisis is made salient, then there is greater polarization of institutional trust.

This hypothesis is tested with the same priming experiment conducted at T1, described above under H1b. We will study this by comparing changes in polarization depending on assignment to conditions. Those assigned to the priming condition are expected to become more polarized on institutional trust compared to those assigned to the control condition. By polarization, we mean that individuals at the lower end of trust and individuals at the higher end of trust are expected to diverge more on institutional trust. A statistically significant test (p < 0.05) in the proposed direction would yield support for the hypothesis.

As before, institutional trust is measured with the following question: “Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?” There are five response options, “Very high trust,” “Rather high trust,” “Neither high nor low trust,” “Rather low trust,” and “Very low trust.”


H4: The coronavirus crisis increases the polarization of social trust.

This hypothesis concerns potential heterogenous changes in social trust as a consequence of the coronavirus outbreak. We will study this by comparing changes in attitudes from T0 and T1. Individuals at the lower end of trust and individuals at the higher end of trust are expected to diverge more on social trust at T1 compared to T0. A statistically significant test (p < 0.05) in the proposed direction would yield support for the hypothesis. Participants in the treatment group at T1 will not be part of this analysis. 

The analysis will rely on the individuals who gave a valid response to the question at both T0 and T1, and were not part of the treatment group at T1.

At both T0 and T1, social trust is measured by asking: “In your opinion, to what extent is it generally possible to trust people?” There are five response options, “1 People cannot generally be trusted,” “2,” “3,”, “4,” and “5 People can generally be trusted.”

We will also explore if the priming experiment increases polarization of social trust, but do not formulate a hypothesis regarding this because the outcome variable is placed further down in the questionnaire. 

We will also explore if there is less polarization on social trust at T-1 compared to T0 and T1. 


The relationship between institutional trust and social trust

H5: A higher level of institutional trust leads to a higher level of social trust.

During the coronavirus crisis, many things are in flux. We expect that even though there is a relatively short time period between T0 and T1, which stacks the odds against finding support for the hypothesis, institutional trust is influencing social trust. 

At both T0 and T1, institutional trust is measured by asking: “Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?” There are five response options to the question, “Very high trust,” “Rather high trust,” “Neither high nor low trust,” “Rather low trust,” and “Very low trust.” 

At both T0 and T1, social trust is measured by asking: “In your opinion, to what extent is it generally possible to trust people?” There are five response options, “1 People cannot generally be trusted,” “2,” “3,”, “4,” and “5 People can generally be trusted.”

We will test the hypothesis with different statistical approaches, including dynamic panel data estimators, and compare the relative fit of the models. A statistically significant test (p < 0.05) in the proposed direction of the coefficient, i.e. from institutional trust to social trust, would yield support for the hypothesis. If the model benefits from including T-1 measures of social trust and institutional trust, these will be included, but the focus is on the relationship during the coronavirus crisis.

The relationship between institutional trust and social trust (H5) will be supported if the coefficient is positive and statistically significant (p < 0.05). registration_responses.q6.question: Our study primarily relies on two panel waves (T0 and T1). Data collection for T0 took place between February 24, 2020 and March 19, 2020, and data collection for T1 began on March 31, 2020. Data collection for T1 is not yet complete, and we have not received the data from either T0 or T1. T1 has an embedded between-group priming experiment where a third of the invited participants are assigned to the treatment group while the rest are assigned to the control group. The experiment is explained below. We also have information on institutional trust and social trust collected before the coronavirus outbreak. These measures are referred to as T-1. While the focus of the hypotheses are on T0 and T1, when possible, the T-1 measures will be used to explore if there have been changes from T-1 compared to T0 and T1.

registration_responses.q17.question:
Increase in trust hypotheses

H1a: The coronavirus crisis increases levels of institutional trust. 

H1a is tested by examining change over time, between panel waves. We expect there to be a mean increase in the level of support for Swedish government authorities between T0 and T1 because the outbreak of the coronavirus reached a more acute crisis stage at T1. 

Attitudes towards government authorities is measured with the following question at both T0 and T1: “Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?” There are five response options to the question, “Very high trust,” “Rather high trust,” “Neither high nor low trust,” “Rather low trust,” and “Very low trust.” 

In the analysis, response options will be recoded to range from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating a greater level of trust. A statistically significant higher group mean value at T1 compared to T0 according to a t-test (p < 0.05) would yield support for the hypothesis. The analysis will rely on the individuals who gave a valid response (i.e. used one of the available five response options) to the question at both T0 and T1, and were not part of the treatment group at T1 (see below under H1b). 

We will also explore if the mean of institutional trust at T-1 is lower compared to T0 and T1. 

H1b: If the coronavirus crisis is made salient, then levels of institutional trust increase.

At T1, we conducted a priming experiment about the coronavirus outbreak. Immediately before answering the question on government authorities (“Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?”) (i.e. the same question above with the same response options), we randomly assign a portion of the respondents to write about their own thoughts on the coronavirus and its consequences. Specifically, for this group, the treatment group, we ask: “The coronavirus and its consequences are discussed a lot right now. We would really like to know more about your thoughts on the effects of the coronavirus and its results. Write down your thoughts in the box below.” The purpose of reading, thinking and writing about the coronavirus is to prime corona-relevant thoughts among the respondents. The control group receives the same task of writing their own thoughts on the coronavirus at the end of the survey instead. For them, the first question at both T0 and T1 is about institutional trust. A statistically significant higher mean value for the treatment group in comparison to the control group (p < 0.05) according to a t-test would yield support for the hypothesis. The analysis will rely on the individuals who gave a valid response to the question at T1 (i.e. used one of the available five response options).

H2: The coronavirus crisis increases levels of social trust. 

The test of H2 relies on a similar approach as the test of H1a in that it focuses on change over time. Here, however, the focus is on social trust and not institutional trust. At both T0 and T1, social trust is measured by asking: “In your opinion, to what extent is it generally possible to trust people?” There are five response options, “1 People cannot generally be trusted,” “2,” “3,”, “4,” and “5 People can generally be trusted.” 

In the analysis, response options will be recoded to range from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating a greater level of trust. A statistically significant higher group mean value at T1 compared to T0 according to a t-test (p < 0.05) would yield support for the hypothesis. The analysis will rely on the individuals who gave a valid response (i.e. used one of the available five response options) to the question at both T0 and T1, and were not part of the treatment group at T1 (see below under H1b).

We will also explore if the mean of social trust at T-1 is lower compared to T0 and T1. 

We will also explore if the priming experiment increases social trust, but do not formulate a hypothesis regarding this (similar to H1b) because the outcome variable is placed further down in the questionnaire. 


Polarization hypotheses

H3a: The coronavirus crisis increases the polarization of institutional trust.

This hypothesis concerns potential heterogenous changes in institutional trust as a consequence of the coronavirus outbreak. We will study this by comparing changes in attitudes from T0 and T1. Individuals at the lower end of trust and individuals at the higher end of trust are expected to diverge more on institutional trust at T1 compared to T0. A statistically significant test (p < 0.05) in the proposed direction would yield support for the hypothesis. Participants in the treatment group at T1 will not be part of this analysis. 

As before, we rely on the following question: “Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?” There are five response options to the question, “Very high trust,” “Rather high trust,” “Neither high nor low trust,” “Rather low trust,” and “Very low trust.” 

We will also explore if there is less polarization on institutional trust at T-1 compared to T0 and T1. 


H3b: If the coronavirus crisis is made salient, then there is greater polarization of institutional trust.

This hypothesis is tested with the same priming experiment conducted at T1, described above under H1b. We will study this by comparing changes in polarization depending on assignment to conditions. Those assigned to the priming condition are expected to become more polarized on institutional trust compared to those assigned to the control condition. By polarization, we mean that individuals at the lower end of trust and individuals at the higher end of trust are expected to diverge more on institutional trust. A statistically significant test (p < 0.05) in the proposed direction would yield support for the hypothesis.

As before, institutional trust is measured with the following question: “Generally speaking, how much trust do you have in Swedish government authorities?” There are five response options, “Very high trust,” “Rather high trust,” “Neither high nor low trust,” “Rather low trust,” and “Very low trust.”


H4: The coronavirus crisis increases the polarization of social trust.

Individuals at the lower end of trust and individuals at the higher end of trust are expected to diverge more on social trust at T1 compared to T0. A statistically significant test (p < 0.05) in the proposed direction would yield support for the hypothesis. Participants in the treatment group at T1 will not be part of this analysis. 

The analysis will rely on the individuals who gave a valid response to the question at both T0 and T1, and were not part of the treatment group at T1.

At both T0 and T1, social trust is measured by asking: “In your opinion, to what extent is it generally possible to trust people?” There are five response options, “1 People cannot generally be trusted,” “2,” “3,”, “4,” and “5 People can generally be trusted.”

We will also explore if the priming experiment increases polarization of social trust, but do not formulate a hypothesis regarding this because the outcome variable is placed further down in the questionnaire. 

We will also explore if there is less polarization on social trust at T-1 compared to T0 and T1. 


The relationship between institutional trust and social trust

During the coronavirus crisis, many things are in flux. We expect that even though there is a relatively short time period between T0 and T1, which stacks the odds against finding support for the hypothesis, institutional trust is influencing social trust.

At both T0 and T1, social trust is measured by asking: “In your opinion, to what extent is it generally possible to trust people?” There are five response options, “1 People cannot generally be trusted,” “2,” “3,”, “4,” and “5 People can generally be trusted.”
